Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Connecting the proximate mechanisms responsible for organismal diversity to the ultimate causes of latitudinal gradients in species richness.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The latitudinal gradient in species diversity is one of the most striking biogeographic patterns in nature, with species richness peaking in equatorial regions for nearly all groups. Despite considerable effort to understand the origin and maintenance of latitudinal gradients in species diversity, a multitude of potentially interacting, non-mutually exclusive hypotheses exist, and no single over-riding explanation has emerged. However, multiple hypotheses link the latitudinal diversity gradient to a presumed gradient in the strength of biotic interactions between temperate and tropical environments. While biotic interactions are believed to play a major role in the origin and maintenance of diversity and may drive increased rates of adaptation and speciation in tropical regions, this hypothesis remains virtually untested. To bridge this gap, a comprehensive analysis of the evolutionary mechanisms underlying adaptive phenotypic variation in color, vision, and smell across a rapidly diversifying lineage of butterflies will be performed together with field-studies.

Understanding the ecological and evolutionary processes that shape temporal and spatial patterns of biodiversity is a central goal of biology, and an increasingly important facet of the endangered species management, particularly in a time of rapid global climate change. This proposal links biodiversity researchers across the US and Latin America, and will lead to sustained international collaboration; broadened access to STEM fields for women and minorities through targeted recruitment; substantial employment opportunities across institutions and countries; and an enhanced public understanding of biodiversity science and threats to global biodiversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Dimensions Final Outcomes

 

Connecting genetic, molecular, and developmental mechanisms responsible for phenotypic variation to the creation of higher-order species diversity is a particularly exciting, yet lofty goal of evolutionary ecology research. Although generations of biologist have been interested in these questions, it has only recently become possible to connect processes operating at multiple levels of biological organization with our broader understanding of ultimate causation in biodiversity research. Our project attempted to bridge this gap by performing a comprehensive analysis of the evolutionary mechanisms underlying adaptive phenotypic variation in color, vision, smell, and taste across a rapidly speciating clade of butterflies.

 

Commonly referred to as "sisters", the butterfly genus Adelpha ranges from northwestern USA to Uruguay. Containing >90 described species and at least 124 additional subspecies, it is one of the largest Neotropical butterfly genera, with species richness peaking at the base of the

eastern Andes (Fig. 1), where local community diversity can be as high as ~35

species. In addition to the latitudinal and elevational gradients in species richness, extraordinary diversity also exists among species in the morphology of larval stages, behavior, and host-plant specialization.

 

Previous efforts to understand the disparity between the hyper-diversity of Adelpha and less diverse limenitidine lineages (e.g., North American Limenitis) found evidence that an increased rate of diversification associated with colonization of the neotropical lowlands by Adelpha, rather than clade age, was responsible for the higher observed levels of species richness in the tropics. In combination with the extraordinary host-plant breadth of many lowland Adelpha species, this result is consistent with the hypothesis that early shifts onto novel hostplants may have been a key innovation driving the diversification of Adelpha. However, many Adelpha share nearly identical wing patterns (Fig 2) and it has long been hypothesized that mimicry occurs between sympatric species. 

 

We investigated these hypotheses using a combination of phylogenetic and genomic studies combined with large-scale field-based experiments of predation, competition, and niche breadth. Our results demonstrate evidence for 1) widespread convergent wing pattern evolution, 2) a strong association between a major host plant switch to the plant family Rubiaceae and increased diversification rate, 3) Batesian mimicry between sympatric species of Adelpha feeding on host plants in the family Rubiaceae and non-Rubiaceae-feeding taxa (Fig 3), and 4) spatial and temporal variation in the frequency-dependent dynamics of mimicry between convergent forms. Taken together these results suggest that selection at both the larval and adult life-history stage interact to drive to promote rapid adaptation, coevolution, and speciation within this genus.

 

Our project also resulted in the generation of extensive genomic and transcriptomic resources for this dramatic adaptive radiation. These resources, including a de novo reference genome assembly for the closely-related genus Limenitis and transcriptome assemblies for >50 Adelpha species, are being leveraged to further investigate the history of mimetic character evolution within this genus as well as to test the hypothesis that stronger biotic interactions in tropical vs. temperate ecosystems drives a faster pace of adaptation and molecular evolution in the genes underlying chemosensory ecology. 

 

Finally, broader impacts of the project included the training of numerous undergraduate and graduate students, as well as a two postdoctoral researchers.  The results were distributed in peer-reviewed publications, at scientific conferences, and through public outreach via invited annual lectures at science museums.
